trial_identification.studytitle: Spinal Dexamethasone added to Bupivacaine and Caudal block in Pediatric Lower Extremity Orthopedic Surgery. A Prospective Comparative Study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of spinal Dexamethasone added to bupivacaine versus caudal block on duration of block and postoperative analgesia in pediatric lower extremity orthopedic surgery

conditions.healthcondition: Anaesthesiology for pediatric lower extremity orthopedic surgical procedures

interventions.interventions:
Group I (spinal group): dexamesthazone 0.1 mg/ kg added to hyperbaric bupivacaine (0.5 %) given interathecally
Group II (caudal group): isobaric bupivacaine 1.2 ml/kg (0.25%) given caudally.
interventions.comparator: isobaric bupivacaine 1.2 ml/kg (0.25%) given caudally as active control group.

primaryOutcome.outcome:
comparing the duration of spinal block after addition of dexamethasone versus the duration of caudal blockade
The extent of the sensory block is checked by pin- prick every minute till establishment of sensory block.
Motor block clinically checked by, lack of leg movement
successful block ( absence of any gross purposeful muscular movement),
duration of block (defined by return of forceful movement of the legs) measured by minutes.
primaryOutcome.timepoint:
successful block ( absence of any gross purposeful muscular movement),
duration of block (defined by return of forceful movement of the legs) measured by minutes.

secondaryOutcome.outcome:
assess quality of analgesia and motor block postoperative
The quality of analgesia assessed by using an observational pain scale (OPS) assesses parameters (crying, movement, agitation, verbalization and BP change) each parameter was given a score of 0-2.
Bromage scale for assessing motor block. (0 = Able to raise straight leg, full flexion of knee and feet. 1 = Inability to raise leg, able to flex knees. 2 = Inability to flex knees, able to flex ankles. 3 = Inability to flex ankles.)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Patients were evaluated every 1 hour for the first 4 hours postoperative

secondaryOutcome.outcome: perioperative complications were recorded (bradycardia, tachycardia, shivering, headache, urine retention or nausea and vomiting).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: during intraoperative and first 4 hours postoperative

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: patients aged between 1 6 years, both males and females, ASA physical status I and II scheduled for lower extremity orthopedic surgical procedures were included in this study.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: refusal of the parents, infection at the site of the block, bleeding diathesis, children with neurological disorders, and children with known allergy to give local anesthetics.

trial_design.sequence: Patients were randomized into two equal groups of patients via a table of random numbers using a computer software
trial_design.statisticalmethods:
Data are presented as mean +/- (SD) for normally distributed data. Baseline characteristics and outcomes across the groups were compared using the Student's t-test for continuous variables and chi-square analysis for nominal data. All analysis has been calculated using SPSS V.16. A P-value of <0.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance.
The primary point was increase duration of spinal anesthesia in compare to caudal anesthesia duration. For each group for each group 26 patients were required for dexamethasone to increase the mean value of duration by 20% based on a previous pilot study in our institute a = 0.05 and a power of 0.8 with 95% confidence interval.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Addition of dexamethasone was found to prolong duration of spinal block in adults. The primary outcome of this study is comparing the duration of spinal block after addition of dexamethasone and the duration of caudal blockade, Secondary outcome is to assess quality of pain relief and muscle relaxation with hemodynamic stability and rapid recovery between the two groups.
